We hope that you love it!</SPAN></P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 29 Aug 2019 20:55:15 +0000","feedId":10337,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a6e74ab00bb7c487f7bfc36c754786a7","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Richard Tso","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598316639108},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","title":"How to quickly optimize Office 365 traffic for remote staff & reduce the load on your infrastructure","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/office-365-blog/how-to-quickly-optimize-office-365-traffic-for-remote-staff-amp/ba-p/1214571","description":"<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\"><U><STRONG>Update 02 April 2020.</STRONG></U></FONT></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">A genuine thank you all for your feedback around this article. Given the enormous popularity of this subject in the current crisis, we've worked hard over the past few weeks to improve and expand the guidance in this article and as a result, we've moved the Office 365 VPN connectivity guidance to a new home which is linked below. As with this article, we've aimed to provide simple and priority driven guidance to help customers deliver solutions to this problem quickly and securely in this current climate.</FONT><SPAN style=\"color: #0000ff; font-family: inherit;\">&nbsp;</SPAN></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><SPAN style=\"color: #0000ff; font-family: inherit;\">Further we've reached out to key VPN partners who have rapidly responded to provide <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-vpn-implement-split-tunnel#howto-guides-for-common-vpn-platforms\" target=\"_self\">step by step guides</A> on how to configure Office 365 split tunneling/Forced Tunneling with exceptions, within their particular implementation. Cisco (AnyConnect), Palo Alto (GlobalProtect) and F5 Networks (BIG-IP APM) are the first to publish, with more to come over the coming days. Special thanks to those partners for their commitment and rapid delivery of this guidance for our mutual customers.</SPAN></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">New Links:</FONT></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-vpn-split-tunnel\" target=\"_self\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">Overview: VPN Split Tunneling for Office 365&nbsp;</FONT></A></LI>\n<LI class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">I<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-vpn-implement-split-tunnel\" target=\"_self\">mplementing VPN Split Tunneling for Office 365</A></FONT></LI>\n<LI class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2020/03/26/alternative-security-professionals-it-achieve-modern-security-controls-todays-unique-remote-work-scenarios/\" target=\"_self\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">Securing Remote Users (From the Microsoft Security Team)</FONT></A></LI>\n</UL>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">Please continue to provide feedback via the comments section&nbsp;on the articles above and we'll endeavour&nbsp;to respond as quickly as possible and continue to improve the guidance as needed.&nbsp;</FONT></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">Paul &amp; The Office 365 Network Connectivity &amp; Performance team&nbsp;</FONT></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><FONT color=\"#0000FF\">**********************************************************************************************************</FONT></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Original Article below:</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Over the past few weeks, Microsoft, and more specifically the Office 365 Network team have seen a large influx of questions from customers around how best to optimize their Office 365 connectivity as they work diligently to plan for a large amount of their userbase suddenly working from home. We’ve also seen similar queries from customers looking for best practice whilst rapidly enabling their Office 365 benefits, <A href=\"https://products.office.com/en-us/microsoft-teams/group-chat-software\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Free Teams plans</A> or <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/e1-trial-license\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">free 6 month E1 trial</A> recently announced to rapidly roll out Teams to allow their business to continue to function and allow users to collaborate effectively without being in the Office. &nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">The recent COVID-19/Coronavirus outbreak has caused many customers to rapidly enable, or proactively plan for the bulk of their employees working from home. This sudden switch of connectivity model for the majority of users typically has a significant impact on the corporate network infrastructure which may have been scaled and designed before any major cloud service was rolled out and in some cases, not designed for a situation when it is required simultaneously by all users.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Network elements such as VPN concentrators, central network egress equipment such as proxies, DLP etc, central internet bandwidth, backhaul MPLS circuits, NAT capability and so on are suddenly put under enormous strain due to the load of the entire business using them, with the end result being poor performance and productivity coupled with a poor user experience for those users forced to adapt to working from home.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A simple diagram of a traditional network model can be seen below, where remote user's connectivity is forced in and back out of the corporate network to reach critical resources as well as branch offices using MPLS circuits to reach the services offered at head office. It is an incredibly common network model for businesses around the world, but it was designed to be effective for a pre-cloud world.</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"1.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175716iCBBB2911C1150674/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"1.jpg\" alt=\"A traditional enterprise network, which does not work well in a cloud first world\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">A traditional enterprise network, which does not work well in a cloud first world</span></span></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">This model made perfect sense and worked very well when the bulk of applications, data and services resided within the corporate network (the dotted line in the diagram), but as enterprises shift to the cloud, it rapidly becomes a cumbersome environment which doesn’t scale well or provide the organization with any agility to react to situations such as that we face today. Many customers report to Microsoft that they have seen a very rapid shift of network traffic which used to be contained within the corpnet now almost exclusively connecting to some external cloud-based source.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Fortunately, Microsoft has been working closely with customers and the wider industry for many years to provide effective, modern solutions to these problems from within our own services, and also aligned to industry best practice. Solutions that apply very simply and effectively to remote workers as much as they do to branch offices. Microsoft has designed the connectivity requirements for the Office 365 service to work efficiently for remote users whilst still allowing an organization to maintain security and control over their connectivity.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Below we will outline the simple steps an organization can take to drastically reduce the impact Office 365 traffic has on the traditional corporate infrastructure when we have a large percentage of users working remotely all at once. The solution will also have a significant impact on user performance and also provide the benefit of freeing up the corporate resources for elements which still have to rely on it.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Most remote users who are not using a virtualized desktop will use a VPN solution of some sort to route all connectivity back into the corporate environment where it is then routed out to Office 365, often through an on premises security stack which is generally designed for web browsing.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">The key to this solution is separating out the critical Office 365 traffic which is both latency sensitive and that which also puts enormous load on the traditional network architecture. We then treat this traffic differently and use the user’s local internet connection to route the connectivity directly to the service. To do this we need to follow a simple set of actions:</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG><FONT size=\"5\">1. </FONT><U><FONT size=\"5\">Identify the endpoints we need to Optimize</FONT> </U></STRONG></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Microsoft has already identified these endpoints and marks them very clearly for reference. In <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the URL/IP list for the service</A> these endpoints are marked as “Optimize”. There are just four URLS which need to be optimized and nineteen IP subnets. In just this small group of endpoints we can account for around 80% of the volume of traffic to the service and it also includes the latency sensitive endpoints such as those for Teams media. Essentially this is the traffic that we need to take special care of and is also the traffic which will put incredible pressure on traditional network paths.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>URLs in this category have the following characteristics:</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Are Microsoft owned and managed endpoints hosted on Microsoft infrastructure.</LI>\n<LI>Have IPs provided</LI>\n<LI>Low rate of change to URLs/IPs compare to other two categories</LI>\n<LI>Expected to remain low in number of URLs</LI>\n<LI>Are High volume and/or latency sensitive</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>You can also query the <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-ip-web-service\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">REST API Web Service</A> for this information<A href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/Office365NetworkTools/tree/master/Scripts/Display%20URL-IPs-Ports%20per%20Category\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">, and a PowerShell example script</A> which does this and outputs the URLs/IPs/Ports for all three endpoint categories can be found using the link above. &nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<TABLE width=\"734px\">\n<TBODY>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P>Endpoint to Optimize</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>Port/s</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>Use</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P><A href=\"https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Furldefense.proofpoint.com%2Fv2%2Furl%3Fu%3Dhttps-3A__outlook.office365.com%26d%3DDwMFAg%26c%3DfpIeS8RwmHkY2r_dFRL5tQ%26r%3D0IIC0oxOP0KJc9J-FLjyDtnUigRj6OMwgEMS3_B70aw%26m%3DtQbhTkEHnQge8KLgc4fwYmiUy1sARtPdqucrYXNRw-Q%26s%3DK2yXsBTva6elLJkSwAmVwR-8pzSQSe3f1n9DoG_vZDs%26e%3D&amp;data=04%7C01%7CGupta.Sachin%40microsoft.com%7C4ae35f5b65af404e463c08d5853c21a3%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C636561415688589193%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwifQ%3D%3D%7C-2&amp;sdata=M42HYgm5WVQ5DfAczKl1A4R7yZ56l3akItmSJrYxtGs%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-linktype=\"external\">https://outlook.office365.com</A></P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>TCP 443</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>This is one of the Core URLs Outlook uses to connect to its Exchange Online server and has high volume of bandwidth usage and connection count. Low network latency is required for online features including: Instant search, Other mailbox calendars, Free / busy lookup, manage rules &amp; alerts, Exchange online archive, Emails departing the outbox.</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P><A href=\"https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Furldefense.proofpoint.com%2Fv2%2Furl%3Fu%3Dhttps-3A__outlook.office.com%26d%3DDwMFAg%26c%3DfpIeS8RwmHkY2r_dFRL5tQ%26r%3D0IIC0oxOP0KJc9J-FLjyDtnUigRj6OMwgEMS3_B70aw%26m%3DtQbhTkEHnQge8KLgc4fwYmiUy1sARtPdqucrYXNRw-Q%26s%3Dwg2FtqMn6DwjAy0okb960lXWwMa8o6q1Znmq5_XqdZI%26e%3D&amp;data=04%7C01%7CGupta.Sachin%40microsoft.com%7C4ae35f5b65af404e463c08d5853c21a3%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C636561415688589193%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwifQ%3D%3D%7C-2&amp;sdata=lqnF5GmA08e1pabdoxoT0tDlF8iepLIecYRt5IAOP%2F8%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-linktype=\"external\">https://outlook.office.com</A></P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>TCP 443</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>This is use for Outlook Online web access to connect to its Exchange Online server and network latency. Connectivity is particularly required for large file upload and download with SharePoint Online.</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P><A href=\"https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Furldefense.proofpoint.com%2Fv2%2Furl%3Fu%3Dhttps-3A__-253ctenant-253e.sharepoint.com%26d%3DDwMFAg%26c%3DfpIeS8RwmHkY2r_dFRL5tQ%26r%3D0IIC0oxOP0KJc9J-FLjyDtnUigRj6OMwgEMS3_B70aw%26m%3DtQbhTkEHnQge8KLgc4fwYmiUy1sARtPdqucrYXNRw-Q%26s%3DUTpWIR7LAxBcvT1sjRYrO9i2VLhdWLbhWZwysAXYy8k%26e%3D&amp;data=04%7C01%7CGupta.Sachin%40microsoft.com%7C4ae35f5b65af404e463c08d5853c21a3%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C636561415688589193%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwifQ%3D%3D%7C-2&amp;sdata=X2XUzsGq5lf923AdT8c8pJoQ3SEt6KWG7VpLNd%2FkHZk%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-linktype=\"external\">https://&lt;tenant&gt;.sharepoint.com</A></P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>TCP 443</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>This is the primary URL for SharePoint Online and has high volume of bandwidth usage.</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P><A href=\"https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Furldefense.proofpoint.com%2Fv2%2Furl%3Fu%3Dhttps-3A__-253ctenant-253e-2Dmy.sharepoint.com%26d%3DDwMFAg%26c%3DfpIeS8RwmHkY2r_dFRL5tQ%26r%3D0IIC0oxOP0KJc9J-FLjyDtnUigRj6OMwgEMS3_B70aw%26m%3DtQbhTkEHnQge8KLgc4fwYmiUy1sARtPdqucrYXNRw-Q%26s%3D5AqjD3iek_7kZAjSDwe12ZJ-eyhwZOGjUIocHHxiHWA%26e%3D&amp;data=04%7C01%7CGupta.Sachin%40microsoft.com%7C4ae35f5b65af404e463c08d5853c21a3%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C636561415688589193%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwifQ%3D%3D%7C-2&amp;sdata=xv8ldWpUtyTDA8r8i9SaF86l21fBZ7wUyGjIlm3S%2Fks%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-linktype=\"external\">https://&lt;tenant&gt;-my.sharepoint.com</A></P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>TCP 443</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>This is the primary URL for OneDrive for Business and has high volume of bandwidth and possibly high connection count from the OneDrive for Business Sync tool.</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n<TR>\n<TD width=\"243px\">\n<P>Teams Media IPs (no URL)</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"54px\">\n<P>UDP 3478, 3479, 3480, and 3481</P>\n</TD>\n<TD width=\"436px\">\n<P>Relay Discovery allocation and real time traffic (3478), Audio (3479), Video (3480), and Video Screen Sharing (3481). These are the endpoints used for Skype for Business and Microsoft Teams Media traffic (Calls, meetings etc). Most endpoints are provided when the Microsoft Teams client establishes a call (and are contained within the required IPs listed for the service).</P>\n<P>UDP is required for optimal media quality.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>\n</TD>\n</TR>\n</TBODY>\n</TABLE>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&lt;tenant&gt; should be replaced with your Office 365 tenant name. For example contoso.onmicrosoft.com would use contoso.sharepoint.com and constoso-my.sharepoint.com</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>At the time of writing the IP ranges which these endpoints correspond to are as follows. It is strongly advised you use the script referenced previously or the URL/IP page to check for any updates when applying the policy, and do so on a regular basis.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>104.146.128.0/17</P>\n<P>13.107.128.0/22</P>\n<P>13.107.136.0/22</P>\n<P>13.107.18.10/31</P>\n<P>13.107.6.152/31</P>\n<P>13.107.64.0/18</P>\n<P>131.253.33.215/32</P>\n<P>132.245.0.0/16</P>\n<P>150.171.32.0/22</P>\n<P>150.171.40.0/22</P>\n<P>191.234.140.0/22</P>\n<P>204.79.197.215/32</P>\n<P>23.103.160.0/20</P>\n<P>40.104.0.0/15</P>\n<P>40.108.128.0/17</P>\n<P>40.96.0.0/13</P>\n<P>52.104.0.0/14</P>\n<P>52.112.0.0/14</P>\n<P>52.96.0.0/14</P>\n<P><SPAN>52.120.0.0/14</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"note.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/178448i64857F43D2F00BEF/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"note.png\" alt=\"note.png\" /></span></P>\n<UL>\n<LI>TCP ports 80/443</LI>\n<LI>UDP ports 3478, 3479, 3480, 3481</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">IPV6 endpoints can be ignored if not currently required, i.e. the service will currently operate successfully on IPV4 only (but not the other way round). This will likely change in future but IPV4 only is possible for the time being.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>2. <U>Optimize access to these endpoints via the VPN</U></STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\" data-unlink=\"true\">Now that we have identified these critical endpoints, we need to divert them away from the VPN tunnel and allow them to use the user’s internet connection to connect directly to the service. The vast majority of VPN solutions allow <A href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Split_tunneling\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">split tunnelling</A>, where identified traffic is not sent down the VPN tunnel to the corporate network but rather sent direct out the user’s local internet connection. The VPN client should be configured so that traffic to the above, Optimize marked URLs/IPs/Ports are routed in this way. This allows the traffic to utilize local Microsoft resources such as Office 365 Service Front Doors <A href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/azure-front-door-service-is-now-generally-available/\" target=\"_self\">such as AFD as one example,</A> which deliver Office 365 services &amp; connectivity points as close to your users as possible. This allows us to deliver extremely high performance levels to users wherever they are in the world. There is also&nbsp;<A href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/how-microsoft-builds-its-fast-and-reliable-global-network/\" target=\"_self\">Microsoft’s world class global network</A> which is very likely within&nbsp; a small number of milliseconds of your users direct egress, and is designed to take your traffic securely to Microsoft resources wherever they may be in the world, as efficiently as possible.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\" data-unlink=\"true\">The solution would look something like that below.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"2.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175717i3E11937A763C29A4/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"2.png\" alt=\"A client's VPN connection with split tunneling enabled\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">A client's VPN connection with split tunneling enabled</span></span></P>\n<DIV id=\"tinyMceEditorPaul Collinge_1\" class=\"mceNonEditable lia-copypaste-placeholder\">&nbsp;</DIV>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Sounds simple? It is in most cases, but for an enterprise, this shift in connectivity invariably raises questions about security. In the traditional network approach security is often applied inline to network traffic as it egresses to the internet. Proxies and firewalls perform inspection on the traffic to check for data exfiltration, viruses and so on. By bypassing this we are removing this layer of protection we have come to rely on when connecting to the internet. The good news is, for the highlighted endpoints above, Microsoft has numerous features in place which means your security with the modern approach may well be higher than available previously. We will run through some of the common solutions below, not all will be relevant or necessary to all customers, but we will cover the majority of common concerns that come up when implementing modern network connectivity.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>3. Common questions when implementing local breakout and split tunnelling for Office 365</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">It should be noted that the two steps above are all that is necessary to solve the performance/scalability issues if you need to move very quickly given the current situation. The elements below can be added as needed and as time allows or you may have them in place already.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q1. How do I stop users accessing other tenants I do not trust where they could exfiltrate data? </STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A: The answer is a <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/manage-apps/tenant-restrictions\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">feature called tenant restrictions</A>. Authentication traffic is not high volume nor especially latency sensitive so can be sent through the VPN solution to the on-premises proxy where the feature is applied. An allow list of trusted tenants is maintained here and if the client attempts to obtain a token to a tenant which is not trusted, the proxy simply denies the request. If the tenant is trusted, then a token is accessible if the user has the right credentials and rights.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">So even though a user can make a TCP/UDP connection to the Optimize marked endpoints above, without a valid token to access the tenant in question, they simply cannot login and access/move any data.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q2. Does this model allow access to consumer services such as personal OneDrive accounts? </STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A: No, it does not, the Office 365 endpoints are not the same as the consumer services (Onedrive.live.com as an example) so the split tunnel will not allow a user to directly access consumer services. Traffic to consumer endpoints will continue to use the VPN tunnel and existing policies will continue to apply.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q3. How do I apply DLP and protect my sensitive data when the traffic no longer flows through my on-premises solution? </STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A: If required, endpoints can be protected with <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/data-loss-prevention-policies?view=o365-worldwide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Office DLP</A> if required and it’s much more efficient to provide this feature in the service itself rather than try and do it in line at the network edge. <A href=\"https://products.office.com/en/business/azure-information-protection-for-office-365\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Azure Information protection</A> can also be used to provide a high level of information protection if required.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q4. How do I evaluate and maintain control of the user’s authentication when they are connecting directly?</STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A: In addition to the tenant restrictions feature noted in Q1, <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/overview\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">conditional access policies</A> can be applied to dynamically assess the risk of an authentication request and react appropriately. Microsoft recommends the <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/zero-trust?rtc=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Zero Trust model</A> is implemented over time and we can use Azure AD conditional access policies to maintain control in a mobile &amp; cloud first world. Conditional access policies can be used to make a real-time decision on whether an authentication request is successful based on numerous factors such as:</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<UL class=\"lia-align-justify\">\n<LI>Device, is the device known/trusted/Domain joined?</LI>\n<LI>IP – is the authentication request coming from a known corporate IP address? Or from a country we do not trust?</LI>\n<LI>Application – Is the user authorized to use this application?</LI>\n</UL>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">We can then trigger policy such as approve, trigger MFA or block authentication based on these policies.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q5. How do I protect against viruses and malware?</STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A: Again, Office 365 provides protection for the Optimize marked endpoints in various layers in the service itself, <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/Enterprise/office-365-malware-and-ransomware-protection\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">outlined in this document</A>. As noted, it is vastly more efficient to provide these security elements in the service itself rather than try and do it in line with devices which may not fully understand the protocols/traffic.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">For the Exchange endpoints listed above, <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/exchange-online-protection-service-description/exchange-online-protection-service-description\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Exchange Online Protection</A> and <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/office-365-advanced-threat-protection-service-description\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Office 365 Advanced Threat Protection</A> do an excellent job of providing security of the traffic to the service.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q6. Can I send more than just the Optimize traffic direct?</STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A. Priority should be given to the Optimize marked endpoints as these will give maximum benefit for a low level of work. However, if you wish, the Allow marked endpoints are required for the service to work and have IPs provided for the endpoints which can be used if required.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">There are also various vendors who offer cloud based proxy/security solutions called secure web gateways which provide central security, control and corporate policy application for general web browsing. These solutions can work well in a cloud first world, if highly available, performant, and provisioned close to your users by allowing secure internet access to be delivered from a cloud based location close to the user. This removes the need for a hairpin through the VPN/corporate network for general browsing traffic, whilst still allowing central security control.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Even with these solutions in place however, Microsoft still strongly recommends the Optimize marked Office 365 traffic is sent direct to the service.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q7. Why is port 80 required? Is traffic sent in the clear?</STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A. Port 80 is only used for things like redirect to a port 443 session, no customer data is sent or is accessible over port 80. <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/encryption?view=o365-worldwide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">This article</A> outlines encryption for data in transit, and at rest for Office 365 and <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/microsoft-teams-online-call-flows#types-of-traffic\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this article</A> outlines how we use SRTP to protect Teams media traffic.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG>Q8. Does this advice apply to users in China using a worldwide instance of Office 365?</STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">A. No it does not. The one caveat to the above advice is users in the PRC who are connecting to a worldwide instance of Office 365. Due to the common occurrence of cross border network congestion in the region, direct internet egress performance can be variable. Most customers in the region operate using a VPN to bring the traffic into the corporate network and utilize their authorized MPLS circuit or similar to egress outside the country via an optimized path. This is outlined further in this article&nbsp;<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-networking-china\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/enterprise/office-365-networking-china</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Finally, please ask any questions you may have in the comments section below and we will do our best to answer as quickly as possible.</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG><U>4. Further reading</U></STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG><U>General best practice for Office 365 connectivity:</U></STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"http://aka.ms/pnc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">http://aka.ms/pnc</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/archive/blogs/onthewire/__guidance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/archive/blogs/onthewire/__guidance</A></P>\n<P rel=\"noopener\">https://myignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com/sessions/81561?source=sessions</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmyignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com%2Fvideos%2F64276&amp;data=04%7C01%7CPaul.Collinge%40microsoft.com%7Ca0a6acac3faa44f6587908d779887ddb%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C637111499448469755%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C-1&amp;sdata=F36Iy6sAOMBHYHFbxQZ2YeXie5UkNWfkiqX3KjhI2ow%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://myignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com/videos/64276</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmyignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com%2Fvideos%2F64275&amp;data=04%7C01%7CPaul.Collinge%40microsoft.com%7Ca0a6acac3faa44f6587908d779887ddb%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C637111499448469755%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C-1&amp;sdata=jeBDqwTkulg3YjYoHKhL163XjKI9KmkgjSAsDWX9D6A%3D&amp;reserved=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://myignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com/videos/64275</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><STRONG><U>Office 365 Partner Program</U></STRONG></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\"><A href=\"https://resources.techcommunity.microsoft.com/networking/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://resources.techcommunity.microsoft.com/networking/</A></P>\n<P class=\"lia-align-justify\">Current partners are <A href=\"https://www.citrix.com/content/dam/citrix/en_us/documents/solution-brief/citrix-sd-wan-for-optimal-office-365-connectivity-and-performance.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Citrix</A>, <A href=\"https://netfoundry.io/office-365-network-optimization/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Netfoundry</A>, <A href=\"https://www.ntt.com/content/dam/nttcom/hq/jp/business/services/network/vpn/sd-networks/pdf/sd-ns_office365.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">NTT</A>, <A href=\"https://www.silver-peak.com/resource-center/solution-briefs/delivering-highest-quality-experience-for-microsoft-office-365\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SilverPeak</A> and <A 08:50:39","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","title":"Recommended Documents in Office apps and Version History in Office for the web","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/office-365-blog/recommended-documents-in-office-apps-and-version-history-in/ba-p/722356","description":"<P>We are committed to ensuring that the collaboration experience in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint is great for you. This includes ensuring that you can work confidently with others in a shared document and get back to your work quickly. Thus, we are bringing Recommended Documents to the Office apps and Version History to Office in the web.&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We introduced the Recommended Documents section to Office.com and Office on the web in October 2018 which surfaces a curated set of Word, Excel, and PowerPoint documents that may be of interest to you. Using activity signals from across Office 365 such as files in which you are @mentioned, documents others have edited, and those shared with you, we pull together suggested documents to minimize the time you spend searching for the right file. We're bringing this capability to the Office apps on your iOS and Mac devices now, and we will be rolling this out to Win32 over the next few months.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"PowerPoint goodmorning.png\" style=\"width: 650px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/121488iCB48035FC0A6142F/image-dimensions/650x485?v=1.0\" width=\"650\" height=\"485\" title=\"PowerPoint goodmorning.png\" alt=\"PowerPoint goodmorning.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Once you're in a shared document, we want to ensure that you feel confident making changes. Version History lets you see what changes have occurred and revert back if necessary. You've always been able to see the previous versions of your document in Word, Excel, or PowerPoint desktop and mobile apps, by going to File &gt; Info &gt; Manage Document. But did you know you can also click on the title bar at the top of your document and select Version History to see who edited your file and how the file has evolved over time? Click on “open version” to see the previous version of the document and compare edits or restore changes.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-center\" image-alt=\"PowerPoint Info.png\" style=\"width: 651px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/120741i0F84506F8EFDD8FE/image-dimensions/651x416?v=1.0\" width=\"651\" height=\"416\" title=\"PowerPoint Info.png\" alt=\"PowerPoint Info.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-center\" image-alt=\"PowerPoint Annual budget.png\" style=\"width: 651px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/120737iC2B4AC3049E83631/image-dimensions/651x417?v=1.0\" width=\"651\" height=\"417\" title=\"PowerPoint Annual budget.png\" alt=\"PowerPoint Annual budget.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We’re bringing Version History to PowerPoint on the web in June, and will be rolling it out to Word and Excel on the web over the next few months. So if you prefer to work from the browser, you can easily return to earlier versions of the document.</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 27 Jun 2019 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":10337,"bgimg":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/121488iCB48035FC0A6142F/image-dimensions/650x485?v=1.0","linkMd5":"d669ab138a83cba6a8a74e57c203a95e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/25/00-50-42-130_dc237343e4e80f30.webp","destWidth":650,"destHeight":485,"sourceBytes":153351,"destBytes":27628,"author":"The_Office_Apps_Team","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/121488iCB48035FC0A6142F/image-dimensions/650x485?v=1.0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/25/00-50-42-130_dc237343e4e80f30.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/120741i0F84506F8EFDD8FE/image-dimensions/651x416?v=1.0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/25/00-52-43-144_74db7c9b48bca389.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/120737iC2B4AC3049E83631/image-dimensions/651x417?v=1.0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/25/00-52-43-362_d6f362dd23b16c75.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598316639097},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","title":"Office 365 Home and Personal Licensing and Activation Improvements","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/office-365-blog/office-365-home-and-personal-licensing-and-activation/ba-p/788745","description":"<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">Since launching Office 365 to consumers, we have heard feedback from customers about the challenges in installing and using their office subscription across multiple devices. The first step in addressing this issue <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Office-365-Blog/You-re-about-to-get-even-more-from-your-Office-365-Home-or/ba-p/234907\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">happened in October 2018</A>, increasing a single user’s device limits to five (meaning they can concurrently use five devices) for Office 365 Home and Office 365 Personal. Our next step in simplifying use across multiple devices will streamline the activation of a user’s device.</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">Beginning in May, we rolled out the following changes to customers on PCs, followed by Mac devices in July.</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">For customers, here’s what stays the same:</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\"><STRONG>Sign in to activate Office</STRONG>: Users will continue to sign in to activate Office on their devices. When single sign-on is enabled, Office detects the user’s credentials and activates Office automatically.</FONT></LI>\n<LI style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\"><STRONG>Sign-in limits</STRONG>: Users will be able to install Office 365 on all their devices and be signed in to five at the same time. This includes any combination of PCs, Macs, tablets, or phones.</FONT></LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">It's important to stay signed in while you use Office on your device. This is what keeps your Office installation activated and ready to use. &nbsp;</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">Here are the changes that you may notice:</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\"><STRONG>No more prompts to deactivate</STRONG>: Users can install Office on a new device without being prompted to deactivate Office on another device.</FONT></LI>\n<LI style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\"><STRONG>Automatic sign-out</STRONG>: When a user reaches the sign-in limit (five devices), instead of being prompted to deactivate, the user will be automatically signed out of Office on the device where Office has been least recently used. The next time the user starts Office on that device, the user will be prompted to sign in to activate Office.</FONT></LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT face=\"arial,helvetica,sans-serif\">For more information on how sign-in works on devices where Office 365 is licensed, please visit this support article: <A href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/how-sign-in-works-in-office-365-1d646e83-1585-4278-8daf-d4a2cc0905e0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https://support.office.com/en-us/article/how-sign-in-works-in-office-365-1d646e83-1585-4278-8daf-d4a2cc0905e0</A></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 05 Aug 2019 19:18:03 +0000","feedId":10337,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"f27be6b443174f4054cdca5d2376c2d0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Shubham Gupta (LICENSING)","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598316639097},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","title":"Customizing Office 365 ProPlus using the Office Customization Tool for Click-to-Run","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/office-365-blog/customizing-office-365-proplus-using-the-office-customization/ba-p/141932","description":"<P>Today we are announcing a preview of the <A title=\"Office Customization Tool for Click-to-Run\" href=\"http://config.office.com\" target=\"_blank\">Office Customization Tool for Click-to-Run</A>, a simple to use web application that enables desktop administrators to customize Office 365 clients.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Until today, Windows desktop administrators would use notepad or an equivalent text editor to <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/configuration-options-for-the-office-2016-deployment-tool\" target=\"_blank\">compile various XML statements</A>&nbsp;to define the Office edition, feature update frequency, version, language and other number of available settings. This somewhat tedious task, in most cases, would result in installation errors from fouled up manual entries or copy-and-paste actions into the text editor.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>With the new Office Customization Tool, desktop admins can leverage the rich user interface that intuitively shows all available options to build the desired Office configurations. The configuration tool groups the commonly used settings in the following categories:</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>software &amp; language</LI>\n<LI>installation &amp; update</LI>\n<LI>licensing &amp; display</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Each of these areas provide admins with options to help meet their security and regulatory needs.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>One of our favorite additions, is the configuration builder. Desktop admins can quickly see a list of all configuration settings being chosen on the right-hand side of the screen, giving the desktop admin a quick and easy way to see the result of their selections without jumping through multiple screens.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>When all the desired settings have been selected, desktop admins are provided with the option to download the resulting configuration.xml file which is to be used in conjunction with the <A href=\"http://aka.ms/ODT2016\" target=\"_blank\">Office Deployment Too</A>l for the settings to take affect during installation time of the Office 365 client.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Desktop Admin also have an option to upload any previously configured XML files to the configuration tool and modify them with new or existing settings.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>For those of you who are familiar with the old Win32 Office Customization Tool which came with your perpetual (MS Installer) bits, you’ll notice the new customization tool has a lack of install-time user preferences. Over the next several months we will be enhancing the tool to enable desktop admins to select many configurable user preferences that are currently being offered with the perpetual counterpart. We encourage you to try out the new <A href=\"http://config.office.com\" target=\"_blank\">Office Customization Tool</A> which is available in preview today, by clicking on the link or typing <A href=\"http://config.office.com\" target=\"_blank\">http://config.office.com</A> in your browser. Send us feedback and let us know what you think by using the send a smile feature, located on the top right of the web application.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Amesh Mansukhani</P>\n<P>Senior Program Manager - Office Engineering</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 09 Jan 2018 22:49:58 +0000","feedId":10337,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"1bbd2d9ea049cb747984b3eba44a93f0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Amesh Mansukhani","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598316639106},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 08:50:39","title":"Go Dark Mode and more on OneNote","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/office-365-blog/go-dark-mode-and-more-on-onenote/ba-p/653056","description":"<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"pic1.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/116277iB4F850799FDA82E4/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"pic1.png\" alt=\"pic1.png\" /></span></P>\n<P><BR /><BR /></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>This month, we’re excited to bring you some highly anticipated features in OneNote: Dark Mode, Send to OneNote from Outlook, Insert printouts of Office files, and simplified ribbon for OneNote on the web. Read on below for more information on these highly requested features!</P>\n<P><BR /><FONT size=\"5\" color=\"#3366FF\">Go easy on the eyes with Dark Mode</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>You asked, and we heard you. Dark Mode in OneNote for Windows 10 is finally available! It’s currently rolled out to Office Insiders and will be available for all users over the next few weeks. To turn on Dark Mode, head over to Settings in the upper right corner of the ribbon, click Options and select Dark under the Color section to switch your OneNote to Dark Mode. If your Windows Mode is already in the Dark color scheme, then you can also select Use my Windows Mode to turn on Dark Mode in OneNote.</P>\n<P><BR /><BR /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"OneNote_DarkMode.gif\" style=\"width: 900px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/116279i9606648F9B15D7F8/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"OneNote_DarkMode.gif\" alt=\"OneNote_DarkMode.gif\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>As we built Dark Mode, we took many careful considerations to make it a great experience. For example, we aimed to turn the canvas dark along with the rest of the interface, while leaving users’ existing content at the same visibility and contrast as in Light Mode. To achieve this goal, we provided a “Dark Mode lens” through which a user can view canvas content such as text colors, table background colors, text highlighters, and ink colors with the same comfort as in Light Mode without simply inverting colors to the opposite end of the color spectrum. In addition, users are able to create content in Dark Mode that will be equally legible in Light Mode, so other collaborators viewing the same content in Light Mode will not have any noticeable difficulties. &nbsp;</P>\n<P><BR />We are actively working to bring Dark Mode to OneNote for Mac, as well as adjustments to the OneNote for Windows 10 experience that came from early Insiders feedback. If you want to be one of the first people to try out new features in OneNote, <A href=\"https://insider.office.com/en-us/join\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sign up to be an Office Insider</A> or simply opt-in from Settings in your OneNote app.</P>\n<P><BR /><FONT size=\"5\" color=\"#3366FF\">Quickly catalog important emails with Send to OneNote</FONT><BR /><BR /></P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"thumbnail.png\" style=\"width: 961px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/116280iD658FB82F5F3F6AB/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"thumbnail.png\" alt=\"thumbnail.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Send emails and meetings from Outlook to OneNote for Windows 10, OneNote for Mac and OneNote on the web with ease. In Outlook, click the Send to OneNote add-in to open the location picker panel. Find the destination notebook and section then click Send – it’s that easy. Once you go to the selected section in OneNote, your email or meeting will be there.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>If you don’t see the new Send to OneNote add-in in Windows 10, head over to File, Options, Advanced, and scroll down to the very bottom and check that “Use Send to OneNote with OneNote for Windows 10, if available” is selected. Once your Outlook is given the update, you should be able to use this new feature.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"outlook options.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/116281i66D39AF7EF6D706F/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"outlook options.png\" alt=\"outlook options.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>This feature is available on Outlook for desktop, Outlook for Mac, and Outlook on the web and will be rolling out to all users over the next few weeks.</P>\n<P><BR /><FONT size=\"5\" color=\"#3366FF\">Insert printouts of Office files directly in your notes</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Now, you can insert printouts of Word, Excel, or PowerPoint files into your notebooks for more robust content in OneNote for Windows 10. Under the Insert tab, click Printout and select the Office file to insert. Once selected, OneNote will load the printouts of your file onto your canvas.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>This feature is rolling out to all users over the next few weeks. Keep your OneNote for Windows 10 updated and give it a try!</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\" color=\"#3366FF\">Simplified ribbon in OneNote for the Web</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"ribbon.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/116282iC9F954116B9C6D7C/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"ribbon.png\" alt=\"ribbon.png\" /></span><BR /><BR /></P>\n<P>Finally, simplified ribbon has come to OneNote for the web. Enjoy more space on your screen and quickly get to the tools you need with this update. If you prefer to switch back to the old experience, click the View tab and uncheck Simplified Ribbon to refresh and return to the previous ribbon.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We hope you try the features above and look forward to hearing from you. Leave us a comment down below and don’t forget to request features you’d like to see in <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/p/feedback-hub/9nblggh4r32n?activetab=pivot:overviewtab\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Feedback Hub</A>.&nbsp;We’ll see you soon with more updates from the OneNote team!</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 May
